item.description:
7 Summits: A Mountaineering Challenge is a game for one to four players in which players test their mountaineering skills against the highest mountain on each continent. First player to climb the seven mountains wins the game!

Choose which mountains you want to climb at your own pace and in any order that you want. There are ten different mountains from which to choose, each with unique statistics and rewards for successfully climbing them.

Use up to four gear pieces to prevent deadly accidents represented with a roll of the dice. Upgrade your acclimatization to prevent altitude sickness. Choose which climber cards you want to upgrade as you draw them to increase your movement speed on a mountain.

There are many risks for which you must prepare in this difficult challenge of climbing the highest mountain on each of the seven continents, and there are many people who want to climb them before you do. How will you attempt this deadly challenge?

item.description:
Orphanage of Fear is a social deduction game for six to seventeen players in the vein of Werewolf or Mafia. Players are either orphan children or sinister boogeymen. Hiding in plain sight the boogeymen wake each night to drag a child into their realm under the bed to fears upon their fear. During the day they hide themselves behind the masks of their previous victims.

The children have to find out who these monsters are, but they are not entirely alone. In desperation the children can take comfort with what toys the orphanage has, and may draw abilities from the toys themselves. They can shine the light of the magic projector to discover the true identity of the target, shield themselves during the night with their teddy bear, save themselves from the monster in the closet by feeding it their limberjack or hide under the blanket to shield them from all danger, but beware not all toys were placed there for the benefit of the children. The boogeymen can bring their own sackcloth doll to throw off the magic projector and make others perceive an innocent child as a boogeyman.

Unfortunately, the children can’t always rely on toys being there. The orphanage is short, even with many children now missing, and so every round the kindly, but out of his depth, caretaker sees to it that what toys are available are taken back and then given out at random.

Orphanage of Fear uses the traditional day night cycle of Werewolf. During the night the Boogeymen choose a child to drag into their realm of existence, along with the toy they are holding, to feed, and during the day the entire group debates and argues about who the impostors are before nominating a child or children. If only one child is nominated they can drag another child with them to the closet door. The player with the most votes is sent into the closet and gets eaten, along with their toy, by the monster inside. The game continues until either all the boogeymen are eaten by the closet monster at which point the children win or there are an equal amount of children and boogeymen at which point the boogeymen win.

In Hacker Dice players are hackers trying to gain control of a network of servers for their own nefarious (or virtuous!) purposes.

The game combines a Yahtzee-style mechanism of rolling dice with a memory element of remembering the defenses of the servers. Players gain control of servers by breaking through their defenses. They can increase their chances by creating malware.

Stranded is quick easy card game. It is about a group of people who crash land in a forest somewhere and need to survive until help arrives. Unfortunately everyone is out to save their own skin. Can you survive long enough to be rescued?

Game play is for 2-5 players and lasts anywhere from 10-20 minutes. Stranded is played in rounds with the simple mechanics of draw a card them play a card if able. The first player to receive 5 points or hold the highest number at the end of the deck is the winner.

Termity is a strategy game about the grappling of indefatigable insects for 2 to 4 players.

At first glance, life goes slowly on the African plains scorched by the sun. Or so it seems. In the thicket of grass, termite swarms fight relentless battles. It is the territorial instinct that makes them contend perpetually. There is a tangible evidence for their fierceness - huge mounds which contain millions of insect warriors always ready to defend their fortress.

Prove your artifice and strategic thinking ability by fighting for survival with your opponents, conquering mounds and expanding into new territories.

The aim of the game is to take control over enemy and neutral mounds and defend your own nests. The player who has power over mounds with the biggest amount of points at the end of the game becomes the winner.

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

The Shadowrun: Crossfire - Demo Box is a trial version of the game that's perfect for learning the rules. We carefully picked out a subset of the full game that shows off Crossfire's feel and mechanisms in a small, elegant package. The demo box takes you through a shorter, tighter version of the "Caught in the Crossfire" mission included in the full game — it's the quickest way for new players to learn how to play.

Catalyst Game Labs is giving the Shadowrun: Crossfire - Demo Box to select gamers at Gen Con 2013 in mid-August.


The shadows of the Sixth World have every kind of danger you can imagine: ultra-violent gangers, flesh-eating ghouls, mages that summon spirits from toxic waste, backstabbing corporate raiders, hard-nosed police officers, and even dragons. You don't have much — mainly your guts, your wits, and your friends — but maybe that's enough. Between you and your teammates, you can sling spells, hack the Matrix, talk a tiger out of his stripes, and bring down a charging ork from a hundred yards away. Will that be enough to face down the worst the mean streets can throw at you? You're about to find out.

Shadowrun: Crossfire is a cooperative deck-building card game for two to four players set in the gritty, cyberpunk fantasy world of Shadowrun. Play a shadowrunner team and take on tough jobs such as protecting a client who's marked for death, shooting your way out of downtown when a run goes sour, or facing down a dragon. In each game you'll improve your deck with a mix of strategies, while earning Karma to give your character cyber upgrades, physical augmentations, magical initiations, weapons training and Edge.

Shadowrun: Crossfire - Demo Box includes two obstacle decks, a black market deck, a crossfire event deck, a mission sheet, 4 role cards, and 2 product information cards.

Differences from Shadowrun: Crossfire

- The crossfire card deck & obstacle decks are smaller than the full game

- The Demo box contains only 1 scenario (so the only way to play this version) and it is not included in the main Shadowrun: Crossfire game

- There are only four character cards (1 of which is the troll mage card which is not found in the base set, but was reprinted in Character Expansion Pack 1)

- The Demo box does not contain any tokens, and requires the players to use something of their own (coins etc.)

- The rulebook is shorter and does not contain all the rules listed in the base game, but contains information specific to the Demo box

item.description:
From the publisher:

Play with family and friends and recompose Jef, Walter, George, Colette and Nicolas. When it's your go, throw the dice and step by step put the body parts back together. Head, chest, legs, arms - the first one completing a whole body is the winner!

The Glitterati of Bear Valley Hills are at an awards after-party, someone says the wrong thing, then the cakes start flying! Whoever comes out the other end cleanest is the winner.

Bun Fight is a board game in which players move between tables laden with various cakes to grab and hurl at their rivals.

On their turn, a player has a number of actions enabling them to move to a table, grab a cake, push a cake in someone's face (close combat), or hurl it at someone (ranged). "Sweet Surprise" cards may be played at any time by any player, adding effects or helping players avoid/recover from trouble. Cakes (Just Desserts) cause Splat and Stun, and the player with the fewest Splat when the last cake is grabbed wins. Stun causes a player to miss actions but can be avoided by either dropping a cake or discarding Sweet Surprise cards if preferred.

On behalf of the faculty and staff of Masamune Shining Forge Academy, it is with great pleasure that we inform you of your admission to Masamune. You were selected from an incredibly competitive and capable group of applicants, and showed an intense devotion to creating weapons worthy of legend.

Masamune is a game for two to four players, and takes place over the course of an academic year at Masamune Shining Forge Academy. As a pupil at Masamune Shining Forge Academy, you and your opponents will start the game with identical 12-card decks. Over the course of the game, you will forge sentient weapons called Chibis and teach them powerful special techniques to defend the Academy from attacking monsters. Alternatively, you can use Chibis to gain more powerful cards and bolster your deck.

Just like normal schools, Masamune Shining Forge Academy uses Exams to measure its pupils’ academic growth. Every time a new card is added to your deck, there is a chance that the next card drawn from the Academy deck will be an Exam, an intense battle staged by your instructors that lures the monsters teeming in the surrounding forest to attack the Academy! After the fifth and final Exam is completed, the school year is over, and the pupil who harvested the most monsters has won the game!

The year is 008 Post Galactic Colonization. Humans have developed the technology to terraform planets, and it has become a very lucrative business. Terraforming companies now race to newly discovered planets to mold them in the most profitable way possible. They will stop at nothing to satisfy their wealthy investors.

Landed is a competitive tile-laying game where players take control of rival terraforming companies that have simultaneously reached the same newly-discovered planet. All players will sign unique contracts with investors to terraform this new world and claim use of the land. The player who fulfills the most valuable contracts and scores the most points is the winner.

In this 2-4 player, hex tile laying game, you begin the game with 2 contracts and 4 double sided tiles. On your turn, you may complete one of the following actions:

1. Play a tile from your hand, adjacent to any other tile. You may fulfill a contract. Obtain a satellite card if you place a satellite tile next to another satellite tile.
2. Draw tiles until you have a hand of 4.
3. Draw 3 contracts. Choose 1 or 2 to keep and discard the remaining ones. You may have at most 3 unfulfilled contracts at a time.

You may also optionally play 1 satellite card as a free action at any time during your turn.

Play continues clockwise. When the last tile is drawn, the last round begins, with the player who drew the last tile getting the last turn. The player with the most points is the winner.

item.description:
The Sealed Ark is a co-operative game which can be played solo or all the way up to 5 people.

Before you roll the die, you must gather a single focus then roll the die to see where will the spirit appear i.e.
(rolls a 4, a single spirit will appear at that 4th circle.)

Players now have the choice of moving to another circle, perform an ability, banish a spirit or do nothing and keep the focus. If the player rolls a 6 on the die, a spirit will appear at the center of the ark (the void) and a spirit card will be drawn and read out loud and do what it's told.

To win, players must carefully plan out their strategies with each unique spirit of harmony and gather enough focus to seal all 5 circles before the void reaches a total of 9 spirits.

item.description:
Horse and Musket: Dawn of an Era is a simple tactical game system that covers the development of musket warfare from Vienna in 1683 and Sedgemoor in 1685 to Appomattox in 1865. Volume I will cover warfare in the west from 1683-1720, when the bayonet replaced the pike.

The battles included are...

Vienna - September 12, 1683 – “We came, we saw, and God Conquered.”

Sedgemoor - July 6, 1685 – The Bloody Assizes

Killiecrankie - July 27, 1689 – Slaughter at Sundown

Fleurus - July 1, 1690 – The French Cannae

Marsaglia - October 4, 1693 – The Massed Bayonet Charge is Born

Narva - November 30, 1700 – Charles XII Smashes the Russian Army

Chiari - September 1, 1701 – Catinat’s Last Battle

Klissow - July 19, 1702 – Charles XII Invades Poland

Blenheim - August 13, 1704 – “A Famous Victory”

Fraustadt - February 13, 1706 – The Swedish Cannae

Villaviciosa - December 10, 1710 – A Bourbon on the Spanish Throne

Sheriffmuir - November 13, 1715 – Confusion on the Moors

Glen Shiel - June 10, 1719 – Rob Roy’s Last Battle

item.description:
Take on the role of mighty shape shifters. By using powerful attacks and assuming the form of mighty beasts the shifters do battle to see who will reign supreme. The first player to empty their hand is the winner of the duel and can lay claim to the title of the Ultimate Shape Shifter.

Play

Select a Form - Each player selects one Form Card from their stack of face down Form Cards and places in the center of the table but in front of them.

Select a Combat Style - Each player then selects one of their combat style cards from their hand and places it face down besides their form card.

Reveal - All cards are flipped face up.

Resolution: The success of a combat style depends on the form.
If successful, players put the Combat Style Card face down in the discard pile.
If unsuccessful, players put the combat style card back in their hand.

End of turn - Players put the Form Card they just used aside, face-up and return any previously used Form Cards back to their stack.

Winning

The game ends when a player ends a turn with no Combat Style Cards in their hand.

Note

This contains all three Transmogrification Games; Transmogrification, Advance Transmogrification and Epic Transmogrification.

The Endless Land is a game with modular boards that are placed in a different way each game for a new experience each time! Some players will choose dangerous quests and heroic battles to gain victory. Some will set up commerce and trade routes to conquer the land. There is magic and adventure among the dwarves, elves, and humans that live in this realm. Make sure you have plenty of food for the journey and let the quest begin!

On a turn all players will take their actions simultaneously. They travel to a neighboring town (move their player meeple on the board) and collect the goods which have been accumulating there. The board is modular and matches up with other board parts to form a unique terrain each game. Also, the game expands with more 8" X 10" board pieces to form a playing surface as with no knowable end. Each player uses gold, wheat, wood, iron, and many other commodities to build farms, stores, and implements of combat.
Players may also take quests that send them into the lairs of diabolical monsters who are hoarding gold, rubies, and other valuable items. Players can risk sneaking into the dark caverns and taking the loot, but if the monster awakens they are in trouble.
Players can build strongholds so that even when they are not in a town, that town is building up their store of goods.

Players can trade each turn to turn their wheat, sheep, or cattle into food, they can also trade other commodities for food in a town where that is in demand.

Players can travel faster buy buying a horse or boat.

Players wishing to build or buy must have food to stay in a particular place longer to transact business.

Points are gained by building structures and conquering creatures. The player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.

link.value: The Endless Land: The Endless Dwarven Land
The Endless Land: The Endless Elvish Land

item.description:
Dice-based combat with tile-based resource gathering. Spend resources to expand your armies, upgrade soldiers, or climb the tech tree.

The goal of the game is to capture 20 enemy soldiers. The first player to do this wins. However, if all of one player's soldiers have been captured (they have no more on the board or in their reserve pile), then the player who has the highest number of enemy soldiers captured wins.

The board is made up of hexagon-shaped tiles set up in a large hexagon shape. These tiles consist of six different kinds of resource tiles as well as a base tile in the middle of the board and at each of the six corners.

As players move soldiers from tile to tile, they leave behind Possession Markers to claim those tiles as part of their territory.

If you expand too far away from a base tile, another player could move in behind you, separating your territory from a base tile and capturing your soldiers.

Each turn you may collect one resource card for each soldier you have on the board - corresponding with the resource tiles they occupy.

On your turn, you can trade resource cards with other players regardless of whether or not they are your ally. Your resource cards can be spent on a wide variety of items to help you win.

Charlie's Angels (οι αγγελοι του τσαρλι) - The playing pieces travel around the map, including Hawaii, and gather evidence & points. Winner returns to start with enough evidence & points to tell Charlie the name of the criminal.

Comes with paper board, spinner, 8 generic playing pieces (2 each of yellow, red, blue & green), clue cards and instruction sheet.

Discover territories, collect resources, build, upgrade and pass through events!

COLOR: Strategy Board Game is a turn-by-turn multi-player game where players are colonizing territories, collecting resources, building connections and mines, discovering hidden lands and passing through positive or negative events.

It can be played by two, up to four players aged ten years and up. The playing time is around 30 to 60 minutes. The game can be easily played even at the very first time without being an experienced player.

Charlie's Angels Police Stories Game from Greece (ΑΣΤΥΝΟΜΙΚΕΣ ΙΣΤΟΡΙΕΣ) - Based on the TV Series. Players try to track down & capture the suspect.

Comes with 4 playing people pieces, 2 cars, colorful paper board, spinner & instructions.

A horde of terrible creatures are on the rampage in the East. The defenceless trading village of Hilt (located just to the west of Knife Edge pass) has called for heroes to help defend Hilt and the entire western lands from the oncoming horde. Choose between 1 and 3 heroes to defend the pass, defeat the oncoming horde and claim VICTORY! ... plus Hilt is super rich and has many beautiful, eligible, young men and women!

Construct the Pass using between 3 and 5 double sided cards, construct the Horde deck based upon a chosen scenario and choose between 1 and 3 heroes. Each turn a new monster enters the pass. You will need to upgrade your heroes and use all your skills in order to stop the advancing horde.

Beware! If a single monster makes it through the pass or all your heroes die then you lose.

User summary

The action revolves around a twenty-four card chance deck and a pair of six-sided dice, three numbers of each die are green and the other three are red.

Each player begins the game with $40,000. After the deck of cards is shuffled and placed face down on the superfluous game board, the top card is drawn and read aloud to establish the conditions of trades for that player. That player follows the direction on the card. The dice are rolled and the results are enacted based on the chart on the card.

After twenty four turns, the deck is depleted and the Power Play round begins. Each person, in turn, chooses one last trade and rolls the dice and check the card for each individual result.

The final round of play has each player roll the dice one last time to determine if each player must pay a trading fee.

Now, the game is over and the player with the greatest net worth is the winner.

Board game with questions and answers in which you have to guess a character or a place offering clues. The first to reach the final square wins. The board further has a series of boxes that hamper progress in balancing the culture of the players.

item.description:
Espião ("Spy") is a board game from the defunct publisher based in Oporto (Portugal), Karto.

It is a game that somewhat resembles the Chess and Checkers, but with extremely simple and basic rules. With a low level strategy is being accessible to all ages.

Game for 2 players where each has 16 playing pieces: One Boss, 8 agents in the front row, 7 spies in line next to the Boss.
The goal is to "hunt down" the Boss of opposing opponent, much to chess style.

Each player can move a playing piece in turn and the direction of their movement is given by the arrow(s). The only piece that can move without respecting the arrows are the Boss and can only move a single house. Spies can move up to four houses and agents can move up to two houses. The enemy piece is captured when it hits and occupies the house where the opponent's piece.

Portuguese description:
Jogo de Tabuleiro Espião da extinta editora sediada no Porto (Portugal), Karto.

É um jogo que lembra um pouco a Xadrez e Damas, mas com regras extremamente simples e básicas. A estratégia também de um nível muito baixo, sendo acessível a todas as idades.

Partida para 2 jogadores em que cada um tem 16 peças: 8 agentes na fila da frente, 7 espiões na fila ao lado do chefe e um chefe.
O objetivo é "caçar" o chefe de espionagem adversária, muito ao estilo do xadrez.

Cada jogador só pode jogar uma peça no seu turno e a direção do seu movimento é dado pela seta. A única peça que se pode mover sem respeitar as setas é o chefe e só pode mover uma única casa. Os espiões podem mover até quatro casas e os agentes podem mover-se até duas casas. As peças inimigas são capturadas quando se atinge e se ocupa uma casa onde está a peça do adversário.

Players in Qwinto all play at the same time, with everyone trying to fill the rows on their scoresheets with numbers as quickly — and as highly — as possible in order to score the most points.

To set up, each player receives a scoresheet that contains three colored rows of shapes (mostly circles with a few pentagons); the rows don't completely overlap, but they do overlap enough to create five vertical columns of three shapes, with one pentagon being in each vertical row.

On a turn, a player rolls 1–3 dice, with the dice being the same colors as the rows: orange, yellow, purple. Each player can place whatever sum is rolled into an empty shape in a row that matches the color of one of the dice. Two rules must be followed when placing a sum in a row:


 All numbers in a row must increase from left to right.
 No number can be repeated in a vertical column.


A player does not have to enter the number in a row, but if the active player, the one who rolled the dice, doesn't do so, then they must mark a misthrow box on their scoresheet.

The game continues until someone has filled two rows on their scoresheet or someone has tallied four misthrows. Players then tally their points: For each completed column on their scoresheet, a player scores points equal to the number in that column's pentagon. For each completed row on their scoresheet, a player scores points equal to the rightmost number in that row. For each incomplete row on their scoresheet, a player scores one point per number in that row. For each misthrow, a player loses five points. Whoever has the highest sum wins!

item.description:
When Bad Karma Strikes, Pass It On To Other Players!

You can travel down life through good deeds or bad deeds, but karma will follow you either way. In Pass The Karma, your best tactic is to collect that bad karma now and pass it on to your opponents to get the win.

This 2nd entry into the Karma Crystals game collection adds a set of elemental shards and a new way to pass on your bad karma to other players. This game also introduces a Karma Crystal scoring system to track all that bad Karma going around. Last but not least, you get 12 new monster elemental cards for your collector’s deck!

Collect up to elemental elemental shards (up to TWO per type) to represent your forward movement through your karma travels. If you get too many per type, you get Karma Crystals and get a chance to pass their reverse-move effect on your score to other players.

Roll dice to work with the various monster elemental cards - monsters are the good guys and help you win! Determine how many karma moves you score per roll and collect your elemental shards for the match, or pass on your no-match karma to another player! When you get elemental shards of FOUR types, that triggers the end of the game and scores are tallied at the end of the round.

In addition to the unique dice matching game mechanic, a unique auto player system is used to facilitate up to EIGHT total players per game. The game also provides an easy way to track multiple game wins for playoffs in case you have more than 15 to 20 minutes to play. No paper score cards and pencil needed - just Karma Crystals, crystal cubes and elemental shards to track and build your score.

item.description:
Le Petit Chaperon Rouge ("Little Red Riding Hood") is a cooperative memory game. The goal of the game is to find pairs of the same tiles while trying to avoid the wolf tiles. When you find a pair, The little red riding Hood advances towards Grandma's house, but if you flip a wolf tile, then the wolf advances. The players need to arrive at Grandma's house before the wolf does. There is also a Hunter tile which resets the Wolf back to its cave when revealed, but is then removed from the game.

From the publisher:
Le Petit Chaperon rouge est un jeu de mémoire où les surprises ajoutent au plaisir!

Tu dois former des paires de provision pour faire avancer le Petit Chaperon rouge sur le chemin de la maison de Mère-Grand.

Prends garde au loup! Seul le chasseur peut l'empêcher d'arriver chez Mère-Grand avant toi.

Sail and Steam Navies is a PDF set of rules designed for 1/600 scale miniatures, but has information for use with 1/1200 scale miniatures. The period covered is 1840 to 1880 when most warships were equipped with sails as well as steam power. The basic rules are 40 pages long, with charts, markers/templates, an example of play, and conversion information for 1/1200 scale. The Under Both Flags module is included and adds six scenarios, a scenario generator, and log sheets for the ships. There are over 1000 log sheets representing almost every ship involved in the American Civil War and a number of forts and shore batteries. Sets of 1/1200 scale counters in PDF format are available separately for use instead of miniatures.

Players may fight historical battles using one of the 6 scenarios provided or create their own using the scenario generator. Game length will vary depending on the number of ships used and scenario victory conditions. Most scenarios played at conventions with multiple players last 3 to 5 hours. 
 The game uses D10s for resolving combat and other actions. Usually you will only need one or two dice but more will be required for most damage checks. D6 dice are used to record momentum for each ship. A player aid and a sheet of markers/templates will need to be printed out for use. As with most miniatures based systems any flat playing surface can be used and a ruler or measuring tape is required for checking range and movement.

The turn sequence is straightforward; it starts with writing speed orders for the turn (how fast the ship will go for the turn), followed by combat (cannon fire, musket fire, boarding/melee), then movement, and finally morale checks and repairs.

From the publisher:
Welcome to the world of Two Hour Wargames!

Chain Reaction 2015 is an introduction to Two Hour Wargames. It’s a complete game – not a teaser – and is free. Chain Reaction 2015 is a set of man-to-man combat rules that can be played in a variety of periods and with any figures you may already have.

Chain Reaction 2015, like all THW games, can be played solo, cooperatively – all players on the same side – or competitively – head to head. Inside you’ll find:

 The current Reaction System, used in all Two Hour Wargames, that allows you to learn one set of mechanics to play a variety of periods.
 Quick game mechanics that yield realistic shooting and melee results. 
 Three scenarios that can be played over and over with no two games ever being the same.
 Character advancement based on your success in each game.
 An easy to use Campaign system that generates your next game based on how well you’ve done.
 Ways to generate your characters and your opponents – Police, Gangers, Militia, Guerillas, and Military.
 All this and more…




Chain Reaction 2015 lets you to learn the current version of the Reaction System used by THW without spending a dime. While our counterpart Swordplay is about hand-to-hand combat with sword and shield, Chain Reaction 2015 is about modern firearms.

Chain Reaction 2015 gives you a chance to see if you like the Reaction System, before trying one of our period specific games. Think of Chain Reaction 2015 as a preview of our other period specific games like 5150: Star Army, All Things Zombie – Final Fade Out, and NUTS!

Replaced by Chain Reaction 2018.

Charlie's Angels Throws Bullets (Lanza Balas) skill game with Farrah Fawcett, Kate Jackson and Jaclyn Smith pictured.

RULES: 
1) Tap & tilt cardboard so that bullets begin in the start position and enter maze.
2) The goal is to get each bullet in its own chamber.
3) Each bullet that enters the waste area become "loose cannonballs".
4) When 5 bullets become loose cannonballs, the game is over.
5) The player who places the most bullets in chambers in the shortest time wins.

This game originates from isolated indigenous tribes of Siberia. It was recently discovered by "mainland people" and immediately caught attention of Lame Heron Games. This superficially simple game turned out to be a marvel of an alien mathematical genius. It is unusual and elegant beyond words, it is very easy to learn but very hard to excel at.

Its unbelievably concise rules, while being simple enough for a child to learn, generate a strategy as complex as the best known "western" games.

The core of the game's mechanics is the notion of dice-perfection:
A die is perfect when the number of pips on the face of the die equals the number of dice neighboring it, regardless of those dice ownership and pips.

The drama of the game is that this perfection status (and therefore the goal) is very fragile.
The conflict of the game is that manipulating their own dice only players affect the status of the opponent's dice as well.
The trickery of the game is that the goal is impossible to achieve using only your own dice.

In Kingpins, you’re running a criminal syndicate in 1920s Temperance Town. The onset of Prohibition means it’s a race to see who will become the best bootlegger in the business! Recruit the right ne’er-do-wells to your side and undercut your rivals at the right moment to ensure that your syndicate comes out on top.

The goal of the game is to be the player with the lowest score after five rounds of play. Cards left in your hand at the end of a round will add to your score. Play smart and leverage your cards’ special abilities if you want to win!

Shuffle the deck and deal five cards to each player.
Place the remaining cards in a face down stack in the center of the playing area. This is the stockpile.Flip the top four cards of the stockpile face up and place them north, south, east, 
and west of the stockpile. These are the recruitment stacks.

GAMEPLAY
The game lasts five rounds. In each round, players take turns in clockwise order until the round end is triggered (see ROUND END).

On your turn, you may take any number of the following actions, in any order:

 Play a kingpin (12) from your hand to start a new syndicate stack in an empty space on one of the four corner positions around the stockpile (NE, SE, NW, SW). 
 Play a card from your hand to any stack. The card you play must be the next lowest in rank, but opposite in color (e.g., You can play a red 10 on a black 11). 
 Move an entire stack onto any other stack. This is only possible if the bottom card of the stack being moved is one rank lower and opposite in color to the top card of another stack (e.g., a stack of R4-B3-R2 can be moved onto a stack of R6-B5). Recruitment stacks can be moved onto syndicate stacks, and vice versa.
 Play any card from your hand to one of the original (N, S, E, W) recruitment stacks that has become empty.
 Discard a femme fatale card to play a different card from your hand to the bottom of any stack. The card played must be one rank higher than the card currently on the bottom of the stack, and opposite in color. 
 Play a hideout to any stack. This is only possible if the top card of the stack is a 1 and opposite in color to the hideout. 
 When you play a card, resolve its special ability (if any) immediately. If the ability cannot be resolved, simply ignore it.




If, after playing a card, you have none left in hand, the round ends. If you have cards left but cannot or do not want to take any more actions, end your turn by drawing a card from the stockpile.

If the stockpile runs out during the round, continue to play as normal but do not draw.

ROUND END
The round will end either (a) when one player manages to get rid of all the cards from their hand or (b) when the stockpile has run out and all players have passed consecutively—whichever comes first.

Score all cards remaining in your hand at the end of the round (taking all special abilities into account). The scoring value of each card is indicated in its bottom right corner. Add your score for the round to your running total.

GAME END
After the fifth round is complete, the game is over. Players should then compare their scores. The player with the lowest total score is the winner—the true kingpin! If there is a tie for lowest total score, the tied player who won the most rounds is the winner.

Kannst du Rechnen? Piratenstarke Schatzsuche is an action game, a treasure hunt. Players take the role of pirates, roll the dice and try to move to the beach token that have exactly same number of shells as the sum of the dice. Count the dice properly together, and go with your pirate on the right beach tokens. Whether you've calculated correctly, you see when you turn the card. Who's at the Pirate Flag get a treasure chest full with gold, and you can also grab chest from the other players with your hook. When all treasure chests are obtained by players, the one who got the most gold pieces win the game!

Pocket Sports Cycling is a competitive dice game for 1 - 4 players. Each player controls a team/rider as they travel through 42 stages over 3 countries.

The game includes 6 custom dice, 4 team cards showing a rider and his unique abilities, instructions, 3 country courses and 12 wooden cubes to track fatigue, H2O and position on the Leaderboard.

A simple mechanic uses a control die that determines what style of attack a rider will use, attempting to overtake the rider in front. Each attack has an 'intensity' value that the Peloton must equal or better to stifle the attack.

There are decisions to be made on when to use special abilities and skill checks to avoid hazards.

It's fast, dice rolling action, that fits in your pocket.

Pocket Sports Hockey is a fast, dice rolling game of Ice Hockey.

The game uses 8 custom made dice with a positional player system that 'calls' the play as it happens on the ice. It's a very rapid, light game that captures the theme of Ice Hockey.

There are 4 positions on the ice. Defense, Wings, Center and a Star Player. The game sees the 'puck' being moved from position to position and shooting on goal.

Your opponent controls a Goalie die to roll and make saves, and a 'check' die for making big hits against the player with the puck.

4 International Team cards are included with a goal scoring track and Power Play track, that uses cubes to easily keep score.

A simple light filler, the player to first score 6 goals wins the game.

Packed with check hits, shots on goal and even fights, this perfect pocket sized hockey game will be suitable for any hockey fan

A Little Card Game for 2-5 Players.

After a particularly thorough round of assassinations in the capitol, the Monarch and the entire royal family are dead. 
You are one of several despotic aristocrats in the tiny village of Lionsgate. You've heard some troubling rumors that the person next in line for the throne is a commoner from your village. This could prove problematic, since you've never been much of a friend of commoners. You lose sleep at night imagining your comeuppance.

At the start of a round of Village Royalty, one card is hidden away. This is the Monarch. At the end of the round, any villagers from the same guild as the Monarch are worth twice as many points.

On each player's turn, they first add a villager card from their hand to the Market in the middle of the table. They then have a chance to bribe a villager, either from the market, or from another player, for one more coin than the villager already holds. After bribing a villager, the player can use the villager's action, which might earn them more coins, points, or some other advantage.

Play continues until a player either has no cards or no coins. The Monarch is revealed, and points are counted. Continue playing rounds until someone reaches 20 points.

From the publisher:

An easy card & board & drinking game with many mini games, simple rules and cruel skills.

Every player draws a card at their turn. There are 3 types of cards in the deck: a mini-game, a skill and a rule.

 If you draw a mini-game, you are going to play the game that is displayed on the card. Mini games are super easy to play and very exciting.
 If you draw a skill, you can use it anytime you want. Items are powerful abilities that can be used to attack your enemy.
 If you draw a rule, from now on, everyone must obey this rule.




Every time you lose a mini-game, disobey a rule or get hurt by a skill, you have to move your pawn on the board.

The player that reaches the exit first, has to drink the King's s shot. This is a mix of different drinks in one glass. Cards in the deck decide when & who is allowed to create this disgusting cocktail.

In City Council each player takes the role of a council member of a newly founded city. The government will select the members of the city council for the first few years until the city rises and flourishes, by which time the most popular member will receive the position of Mayor.

In order to build the city, you and the other councilmen must maintain a low level of pollution, fight crime, create jobs, and sustain an adequate city budget. If you and the others don't keep up the good work, the city project might not succeed, the government will take over, and all players will lose.

As a member of the council, you must also strive to gain the favor of the different political groups who rule the streets of your city. As the game progresses and the city grows larger, more and more political interest groups will try to impose their will on the city by knocking on your office door and asking you for small "favors" in which you will have to act on their behalf. In return, they'll offer you their support and you'll receive victory points for your personal cause, possibly allowing you to become the city's first Mayor.

City Council: Deluxe Edition contains the original game along with one expansion:

• City Council: The Disaster Deck consists of ten event cards that disrupt "normal" city life by causing havoc everywhere, and it introduces a new game mode, creating a fully co-operative experience for City Council players. In each round of play, the players change roles, taking crucial steps to prevent these events from tearing apart the growing city.

City Council: Deluxe Edition was originally, erroneously, reported to contain the City Council: Government Agent expansion.

item.description:
Tsair Deng (Slant nail) is similar to One Arm Joe, except that it is played with Chinese dominoes instead of a standard double six set. Also similar to the Korean game of Dancing Dragons, which is essentially the same game played with two open ends instead of one.

If four people play, each is dealt 8 tiles. If three people play, each is dealt 10 tiles and the remaining two are not played. If two people play, each is dealt 16 tiles.

For the first tile laid, the leader must declare which half is 'open'. Then all dominoes are connected to the only open half of the boneyard, in a straight line. Once the boneyard counts a multiple of eight dominoes, the dominoes are stacked backward upon the previous row. The boneyard can therefore count up to four rows.

Whenever a player is unable to play, he must discard a tile from his hand facedown.

When all the players' hands are empty, the round is scored. Each players counts the pips on his tiles, and must pay to his opponents with lesser scores the difference in points. If a player manages to play all his tiles, this scoring difference is doubled.

ΤαξÎ¯δι στο ΧρÏŒνο ("Time Travel") is an educational game in which 2-4 players are been asked about important facts from history of Greece and the other world. The game is played with four different ways, depending on the difficulty you want to play, if you want to use sand timer etc.

The game consists of 500 cards, 200 blue(easy) and 300 red (difficult) and 1 sand timer, and every player can choose the color of the card, so children with different ages can play together.

In 2012 the Institute of National Remembrance published a game called “ZnajZnak”. The game is the history of Poland told with 133 symbols. Playing “ZnajZank” makes it unbelievably easy to remember the most important figures, dates, places and objects in Polish modern history.

ZnajZnak - Sport is an educational game for 2 to 8 players about sport in Poland (1918-1945). The 133 symbols placed on the game cards were carefully selected to show best sportsmen, club badges, world records and many more.

ZnajZnak - Sport includes 63 cards on each of which 12 different symbols have been placed. Every two cards have a common symbol. Your job is to find and name it as fast as you can. If you don’t recognize your symbol flip your card and read the information on the other side. Then place a new card on the back of your deck and go on with the game. If you manage to name your symbol you should give your card to the player on the left. The first player to get rid of all his cards wins.

User summary:
ãŸã­ã¾ã (Tanemaki) is a card game from Hoy Games that bears similarity to Bohnanza in theme and scoring, but the basic gameplay is significantly different.

The similarities are:
Players are farmers growing different crops in up to two fields.

When these crops are harvested, they turn over into coins (Hoyer) according to the distribution on the crop. The design of the cards looks similar to Bohnanza in this respect.

The difference is the way cards are distributed. The active player draws a hand of cards from the draw deck, drawing the number of players plus one. They choose an opponent and pass them a seed card face-down in secret. That player has three options: to either plant it face-up in their own field, or place it face-up in the Storehouse in front of the active player, or pass it face-down to another player who is still in the round (who then has the same options but cannot pass it back). Once a player plants a seed card in a field, they are out for the round. Eventually, all the other players will have planted a seed card, or added the seed card to a field with that crop. The active player is left to choose their seed card from what is left in their hand or what is in the Storehouse (which can store 2 cards). The remaining card is discarded. The turn passes left to the new active player.

If a player has their two fields occupied, and has to plant a seed which does not match the two crops, they must harvest one crop. As well as the seed cards, there are manure cards which act as Jokers. Planted cards are staggered to show how many are in a field, so any Manure cards go at the back of the stagger.

Play ends when the active player cannot draw enough cards to distribute. The player with the most money winds, ties are broken by owning the most of the rarest plants.

So whilst Tanemaki has obvious connections to Bohnanza, the game play is calculated and based on hand management from the card draft, and no bartering is involved.

The 2nd edition includes English rules. The differences between the 1st and 2nd editions are:
- Redesigned the box
- Reduced card size
- Improved card quality
- Redesigned the back of the cards

You are a farmer, who's trying to grow vegetables.
Collect the seeds, plant as many as possible and then harvest them for coins.
The player with the most coins wins the game.

A small version of the famous game, specially produced for the Nestle Company and it promotes the healthy ways of life.

The box contains everything you need to play, a folded board, a die, 6 different plastic player tokens with 36 pieces, and a deck of cards, that have the following categories of questions:
1. Diet and Health
2. Workout
3. Entertainment,Hobbies and Relaxation
4. Ecology and Environment
5. Science and Technology
6. Geography and History

This product is for promotional use only

link.value: The All Canadian Trivia Board Game

item.description:
The charge is set, the choppers are primed, and the riding conditions are nearly perfect. It's time to shred this slope like no other!

In Avalanche, each player assumes the role of an adrenaline crazed snowboarder, and participates in an event where riders deliberately race an avalanche (and each other) down the mountain. It is of course important to stay in front of the snow, and to try and finish the event first, but what really matters to these shredders is bragging rights. In the end, whoever has the most to brag about wins!

Each round, players will simultaneously choose up to three action cards to bet, and place them face down on the table. Once everyone has decided which moves they want to try and pull off, they reveal their cards, and each player rolls in turn order for the resources they need to successfully complete their actions. Some actions are easier to pull off than others, but will usually grant you either fewer bragging rights, less combo, or less movement.

After each player has completed their rolling phase, the avalanche is advanced, and anyone who is caught by it must subsequently roll for an immediate rescue. Once they've managed to successfully latch onto a helicopter, they lift out, land one space in front of the avalanche, and a new round begins.

It's "Pictionary in a can" with the Pictionary Dice Game. The new twist on the classic drawing game has two players rolling dice to decide what to draw next. Out of three descriptor dice and three subject dice, the players choose a die from each category to make a unique combination. The artistic battle is then on.

Draw as quickly as you can to help your team guess the combination. Your opponent's doing the same thing. The first team to guess right scores the point. The first team with five points wins it all, including the coveted bragging rights. Add this to family game night or pull it out at parties for an unforgettable game night full of laughs and really bad drawings.

name.value: Dick: A Card Game Based on the Novel by Herman Melville

item.description:
Dick is a party game in which you use direct quotations from Herman Melville's 1851 novel, Moby-Dick, to propose answers to mock-serious questions. It is a game about playing irreverently with words and meanings.

In each round, one player serves as a judge and reads aloud a question or fill-in-the-blank prompt from a green card. The other players submit white cards, each containing a verbatim quotation from Moby-Dick, as suggested completions for the prompt. The judge reads all the submissions aloud and chooses the best one, construing "best" however he or she sees fit. The winner keeps the green card, everybody replenishes their white cards, and the role of judge rotates to the next player. At the end of the game, whoever has the most green cards wins.

The game depends on understanding the particular wit of the other players and strategically playing answers to appeal to each round's judge. The sheer irreverent weirdness (sexual and otherwise) of Moby-Dick is what makes the game exciting and hilarious.

item.description:
The Devil's Bedpost - A quick 2 player game of card drafting.

As working class MUBs (monsters under the bed), your and your opponent dream of becoming middle monster management in the Devil’s hellish hierarchy. To that end you decide to compete in the annual MUB evaluations. You are each given a target bedroom and all the devilish tools at your disposal to keep your sleepy victim awake all night. The MUB who earns the most points after eight hourly rounds of mayhem and mischief will get a promotion, the other MUB... well, they’ll get what’s coming to them...

Setup: 
Shuffle the deck of cards and deal 16 cards to each player. The remaining two cards will form a discard pile. That’s it.

Game Phases: 
There are 3 phases to each round: 
1. Play 2. Discard 3. Pass.

1. Play:
During this phase each player will play one card from their hand face down, then reveal at the same time and place it in their ‘bedroom’. On the first turn, players will place the card down in front of them. On consecutive turns each additional card will be placed adjacent to one already played. Cards will form a rectangle of 8 cards by the game’s end. It does not matter which end of the card line the adjacent card is played to.

Each bedroom has 4 sides and 4 corners. Top and bottom sides of the bedroom are opposite each other. Left and right sides of the bedroom are also opposite each other. Cards may never be moved in a bedroom unless the special action on a card allows it.

After playing a card each player must use the special action of that card, if applicable.

2. Discard:
Players now each discard from their hand face down to the discard pile.

3. Pass:
Players now pass their remaining hand of cards to the other player.

Game End and Scoring:
After each player has placed their eighth card in their bedroom, and discarded the final card from their hand to the discard pile, the cards are scored.

The top of each card shows its point value (as well as a small black number which shows how many of those types of card are in the deck).

Many of the cards have special actions which give scoring bonuses depending upon position and/or number of cards. The player with the highest score is the winner. If players are tied, the player who sleeps the longest the next night is declared the winner.

item.description:
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse come to Earth to collect all souls.

The goal is to bring about the Awwpocawpse by riding the planet of its entire population in 4 turns. Be the horseman with the greatest collection of souls at the end.

Each player take one horseman (Death, Famine, Pestilence and War) and moves over the game board (the world) and snap up as many souls as possible. Each time they can use 3 Action Points to achieve that goal. Actions that can be taken are:

 Move to an adjacent territory
 Reap: take a population token from the territory they occupy or adjacent to.
 Use a special ability, as described on the character's card.




The game is oriented at children.

In Morocco, players are families of artisans carrying on the ancient traditions of the world famous Jemaa el-Fnaa market square in Marrakech, Morocco. Each day, they work to claim the best stalls across the market and attract customers to sample their wares or be enthralled by their amazing spectacles.

It is going to be an extra busy day so the families fight even harder to claim the their needed space. The ancient families of snake charmers, water sellers, rug merchants, magicians, and food sellers work hard vying for the best stalls.

In Morocco, players will send their workers out to try and claim stalls at the market. When enough workers from the same family have made it to a stall, that family claims it and clears out any adjacent juice sellers.

Morocco is played over two separate phases: scout the market and assign workers. In the first phase, players use the nearby roof to scout the market and determine where the busiest stalls will be. In the second phase, players use the gained information to send workers out into the market.

item.description:
You and your opponent have a team of 3 Robox that are fighting to see who is the best, and the player who defeat the opponent's team will be the winner. Both start with 1 active Robox and the other two will be in the reserve waiting to fight and helping to the active one. Plus, every Robox will be secretly configured with one of the 4 Special Powers.
On your turn you have to pick 2 of the 7 possible actions:

 Attack: Only the active Robox can attack. Roll a die, if it's equal or less than your Attack Power (energy tokens + base point), remove 1 Energy Token from the defense of the opponent's active Robox.
 Charge: If your Robox is in the Potentiate Position, change it to the Charge position and add 1 Energy Token from the pool to its Defence.
 Potentiate: If your Robox is in the Charge position, change it to the Potentiate position and move 1 Energy Token from the Defence to the Attack.
 Accumulate: Only the Active Robox can accumulate. Put 1 Energy Token from the pool next to your Robox Card. It will count as an extra Energy to your next attack and then it will go back to the pool.
 Donate: Only the Reserve Robox can donate. Give 1 Energy Token from the defense of this Robox to the defense of the Active Robox; or from the attack of this Robox to the attack of the Active Robox.
 Replace: Switch the Active Robox for 1 of the Reserve Robox.
 Special Action: Use your special power.

item.description:
Trickster is a fun and easy-to-learn card game for 3-7 players, lasting about 15 minutes. Each Trickster set features its own heroes and new ways to play. Find the set that’s right for you... or mix together characters from different sets to customize your own game!

A Trickster set has 49 cards with seven heroes, each with their own simple effect on play. A hero appears in seven different suits, each a color of the rainbow: Red, Orange, Yellow, Green, Blue, Indigo, Violet. Each hero and suit combination appears once in a set.

The first player of each round may play any card from her hand. The second player in the round is called The Trickster, who may also pay any card from her hand. Any subsequent player that round must play a card that follows the pattern set by the Trickster. (If the first two cards are Yellow, then everyone must play a Yellow card.)

If you cannot follow the pattern, you must collect cards played this round into your personal scoring area. If everyone was able to play one card, then the Trickster collects the cards.

The goal of Trickster is to have the fewest cards by the time any player has emptied her hand. Whoever has the fewest cards is the winner... with one exception! If you have more cards of a suit than any other player, you may ignore those cards when scoring.

item.description:
A spin-and-move race game for 2-4 players with a man on foot, a man on horseback, a man in a car, and finally a man in an airplane. All four compete to be the first to reach the City of Gold. The man on horse moves 2x as fast as the man on foot. The car moves 3x as fast and the airplane 4x as fast as the man on foot. The airplane has the longest distance to travel while the man on foot has the shortest.

As in many race games, two players cannot occupy the same space at the same time. The person spinning knocks the occupant back to start. Blue spaces on the board are "safe" spaces where the occupant cannot be dislodged. The player spinning returns to start.

The player with the airplane must hit the red #4 by the exact number to enter the City of Gold. Likewise, the car must hit the red #3, the horse the red #2. and the man on foot the red #1. Only then may the player progress to the finish. The first player reaching the finish is the winner.

name.value: To The Last Drop of Blood The Battle of Kobani October 2014

item.description:
By the beginning of October, 2014, the first set piece battle in the war with the radical ISIS terrorists occurred at Kobani, Syria, along the Syrianâ€Turkish border. ISIS intended to secure this border town to make it easier for their volunteers to enter Syria from Turkey. But, like many battles, it was a battle that need not to have occurred. ISIS volunteers had entered from Turkey from many crossing points but the one difference was its close proximity to the ISIS capital of Raqqa. It was that reason that ISIS decided to fight a more conventional battle this time. It seemed like a sure win as up to 4000 ISIS soldiers gradually descended upon the Kobani area along with some 25â€30 AFVs from captured Iraqi booty when Iraq allowed the city of Mosul to fall. These AFV's, American M1 and Tâ€72M were still formidable weapons even in inexperienced hands and add to this numerous artillery guns from war booty, and ISIS was almost assured a victory. But like at Stalingrad in WW2, where the Russians refused to be defeated, the Kurdish YPG Peshmerga felt the same. Kobani had been in Kurdish hands and as ISIS swept many Kurdish towns into their hands and slaughtered them, the Kurds decided to make a stand.

A map hex is 550 yards across. Each unit represents a 100 men and each turn represents one week. The game lasts from Oct 1 to Jan 15. Leaders represent a single person, while AFVs represent 5 five tanks. Artillery units represent one battery of 4-6 guns.

Create your own adventure on the Appalachian Trail as you hike your way along the nearly 2,200 mile footpath from Georgia to Maine. Prepare for your own WALK IN THE WOODS with this fun new game! GEAR, CHANCE, and CHALLENGE Cards define your journey.

GEAR - Be prepared and learn to use the essential items during the game when faced with emergency scenarios.

CHANCE - Encounter opportunities to race ahead, hazards that slow your pace, or choose to stop and enjoy the trail.

CHALLENGE - Play and learn about hiking first aid, LEAVE NO TRACE camping and backpacking skills, Plant and Animal I.D., and Trail History.

Chance and GEAR Cards interact during the game. When faced with an emergency, if you are carrying the proper equipment, then you can continue your hike. Collect points as you correctly answer questions, identify plants and animals, and use the gear in your pack to help navigate through perilous situations that arise! The game ends when the first player completes a Thru Hike--arriving at either Katahdin or Springer Mountain. All players then tally the points from their Trail Journal cards and the player with the most points is the Winner!

This game is a fun and engaging way to prepare new hikers (kids scouts, students) for a their next adventure! It is also great for seasoned adult hikers to reminisce and test their knowledge! (Did I hear "alternate rules" with adult beverages?) It is also perfect for COUCH POTATOES because it lets them hike the AT from the comfort and safety of their living room! (One of the game pieces is a sofa!)

link.value: The Appalachian Trail Game: The ME-GA Expansion Set

item.description:
Grow Fairy Kingdoms is a Competitive Plant-Growing Game for 3-6
players, ages 6-and-up.

Each player starts with a Base on which to grow their plant.

There are two phases: the Day when each player chooses tiles to grow their plant, and the Night, when each Thorn on your plant is a chance to prune your rivals.

There are four main types of tiles: Stems which cause the plant to branch, Flowers for victory points, Thorns for night-attacks, and Leaves for shielding against attacks.

Rare tiles include powerful gold Flowers, Thorns, and Leaves, as well as tiles to place on opponent plants: Caterpillars (to eat opponent tiles) and Rot (to prevent growth).

In the Night phase, Thorns allow players to roll six-sided die to target the ends of rival plants.

The game ends when at least one player survives a night with at least 5 victory points.

Game comes with 98 tiles and one 6-sided die. No reading required.

From the publisher:

Gallina City is an interactive and exciting family game. Become the boss of the farmyard by finding the identical images as fast as possible.
Be precise with your descriptions and pay attention to the other players’ descriptions. Otherwise you might lose some feathers!

In Gallina City you try to get rid of your cards as fast as possible in three rounds (with progressively increasing hand size at the beginning of them). Cards are composed of four poultry scenes, with slight variations between the quite similar scenes found in different cards.

For achieving this goal every player describes the scenes in their cards at the same time as other players do. In this pandemonium of people talking about chickens, you try to discover who has in her card exactly the same scene as in one of yours. If you are right, each of you discard your card and are one step closer to victory.
If the other players show you that the pictures are not *exactly* the same, both of you get penalized and take another card from the deck.

The round ends when one or more players have exactly two cards left in hand. The rest of the players earn as many negative points as their hand size at that spot.

After three rounds the player with less negative points win.

Gallina City includes rules for a team version.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
From the back of the box:

Looking for an animal! - Who is the first to track down the trail?
We only now it is a predator, living in the jungle, more than 2m long and has sharp claws ...

Sixty yes/no Questions, found on the gameboard, give useful hints to find the animal. Smart combining the questions, which are marked green for correct and red for incorrect, gives you great chances to win the animal card.

Serengeti: A Race For Life is a game for two players set in the African savannah.

In an attempt to preserve the ecosystem and ensure there is a future for its wildlife, your mission will be to study the animals that inhabit the Serengeti.

In addition, you will be rewarded if lions can thrive in the savannah, as long as you can keep scorpions out of your headquarters!

The game takes place over a variable number of turns called seasons. During each season, players play cards from their hand in order to track animals, or to use their skills.

Players start the game with just a few trails, a card that will allow them to track animals from the supply, adding them to their individual deck to adjust it to suit a particular strategy.

Animals provide them with unique ways to deal with the various threats in the game as well as helping them to efficiently manage their resources.

Animals do more than just produce game effects to rely on during the game however, and are a main source of points.

At the end of the game, victory points will be awarded depending on the players’ deck content as well as majority in the savannah.

The competition track may also tilt the outcome in favour of the player who best achieved to stay one or more step ahead of their opponent!
