Serengeti: A Race For Life – The Hunt

item.description:
The Players travel around in Europe and try to get as much Gourmet Awarts as possible.
The player change their role while the Play from dishwasher to Gourmet and back to porters.
Only some roles allow the player to try to get a Gourmet Award.
The Player who has most awards at the end of the game wins.
The game is dice driven (4 travel dice an 1 Hotel die)

Dora the Explorer travels to her friends.
By travelling the kids learn to write the letters of the alphabeth. 
There are 13 cards for the 26 letters. On each letter there are ways where the players figure have to move to the friends of Dora (also on the letter) Which way they have to go is written on the card. There are chips which show each a friend. Finding the right chip allow to move.

With this game the player's reaction on aggressive utterance of the other players is rated.

1 player gives the instruction and makes the Rating (-3 to 3 points for each reaction)

Each player gets 20 of the 120 cards. On a player's turn, another player chooses 1 of his cards and attacks the active player with the aggressive sentence on the Card. The player has to react in 5 seconds. The more positive he reacts (open for further discussions) the more Points he will get from the moderator.

Whoever has the highest positive sum of points after 20 rounds, wins the game.

Note: Although a player count of 8 and a card count of 120 doesn't seem to make sense (8 people would need 160 cards), the player range of 4-8 is given in the rules. No rule change for 7-8 players seems to have been provided.

The player who has first moved all his 4 Pins over the board wins.

The game board is a 6x8 Chess field.

This game is a mixture between Pachesi and Chess.

Players roll a die. With 6 the Player has to place a pin on the first row of the plan.

The figures move like the figures in Chess. Which Chess figure they are at the moment is shown in a little hole in the field where the figure stands. There is a board below the fields. This can be moved in the positions 1-6. Each position changes the chess values for all fields. The rolled die shows on which position this board is moved.

All chess figures of a player on the board are moved in each turn.

The player has to throw out an opponent figure if possible.

The game board shows 4 trees which grow from the center to all 4 edges.

Each leaf of the trees is one field where the figures can move.

There are some spaces between the leaves, where the figures have to move around. The figures can even move from branch to branch or from tree to tree if the leaves are neighbored.

At the beginning of the game places his 8 colored stones on different leaves (2 on each turn until all are placed)

If a Player can jump over an own stone he lines it with other own stoned (jumped over in previous rounds) to a line (namesd snake).
If all own stones (which are on the board) are lined, the player moves his snake instead of his pawn.

If he reaches one of the start fields with his snake he can place the Stones of his snake on the nest fields, in the middle of the board. Fields have to be free.

The number of fields the player is allowed to move his pawn or snake is driffen by an additional figure, the Mungo.

The Mungo is moving on the top line of leaves of the trees (at the edge of the board). The number of leaves the branch where the Mungo is, is the number the Player can move. Additional the length of his snake (number of stones) enhances accordingly the movement number.
The Mungo is moved the doubled number of the calculted movement number.

There are additonal rules for removing and adding stones from the board.

Game ends when all fields in the middle (between the trees)are filled with stones. The player with the majority of stones in the middle wins.

Mathematic think and logic game.

Each player gets the same set of numbers (1 and 2 digits). He shuffles them and takes new that he has again 12 numbers on his hand each round. The player adds 3 stones to his Hand if he cannot do anything on his turn.

The game board shows places for the numbers and the 4 base calculations between them.

Additionally there are rows of number fields, where the player can place series of numbers with always the same difference.

On players turn he can place whole valid calculation, or a part of a series of 3 or more numbers (with the same difference).

A third possibility is to continue a series. The actual player places as much as he can.

If something is wrong, he gets the numbers back and the next player has his turn.

The game ends after the round when the first player has placed all his numbers. The player without Stones wins. If more than 1 has finished the one with the less number of used special marked field wins.

The game theme is based on the comics of Isnogud who always tries to become caliph instead of the actual caliph Harun al Pussah.

The game is about jewels. Isnogud tries to hold four different colors of them to win.

At the beginning Tunichgud (Assistent of Isnogud) has 1 of each 4 colors and Isnogud has 4 from each color.

On a player's turn he rolls the die and moves his 1 figure clockwise or anticlockwise on the track.

If the color of the field is equal with the 1 of the stone Colors the player gets one of this from Isnogud.

If the players have all 5 stones of 1 color they win.

If the Color of the field is black, one of the 12 cards is opened. They show 8 times Isnogud and 4 times the caliph.

If the card shows the fourth caliph the players win if it shows the sixth Isnogud the players lose.

Note: These games come together in one box, and have shared components. The smaller maps for 18MS and 18GA are both on the back of the big map for 18Dixie.

18Dixie is an 18xx game set in the Southeast region of the United States. Players invest in railroad companies in an effort to have the greatest net worth at the end of the game. This is determined by adding the cash holdings of the players to the value of the stocks each owns. The money in the actual companies, though, are separate from the individual player's money. During the game, there are alternating stock rounds, where players buy and sell stock in the various railroad companies, and operating rounds, where the various companies operate. When operating, the companies lay tracks, place stations, and buy and run trains.

18MS is an 18xx game set in Mississippi and Alabama, together with portions of adjoining states. Players invest in railroad companies in an effort to have the greatest net worth at the end of the game. This is determined by adding the cash holdings of the players to the value of the stocks each owns. The game consists of five Stock Rounds, where players buy and sell stock in the various companies, each of which is followed by two Operating Rounds, where the various companies operate by laying tracks, placing stations, and buying and running trains.

18MS is a separate mini game using some of the components from 18Dixie together with some additional components specific to 18MS. 18MS aims to be a smaller, shorter game that may be useful for teaching the 18xx system to newer players.

From the box: "Feed the Sharks! How many words can you make? Use word families to build reading, spelling, and comprehension skills."

Word Shark is an educational board game where players compete to use tiles to build or complete words. It comes with two-sided mats, offering two ways to play.

Side one, the Shark Mat, has five different incomplete words, each with the first letter missing. The letter tiles with consonants are placed in a pile face down. Each player in turn chooses a tile and tries to complete one of the words on his or her mat with the letter. If a word cannot be completed, the tile is returned to the pile face down. The first player to complete all five words wins.

Side two, the Ocean Mat, challenges players to make as many words as possible on their mats. Each player starts by drawing an agreed number of starting red consonant tiles and yellow vowel tiles. Players then work simultaneously to create as many words as possible on their mats. Players may continue to draw or trade tiles from the center pile to continue making words. (The rules do no specify how many tiles can be taken at a time). Players can decide whether to make words individually or in crossword fashion. The winner can be either the player who made the most words or the player who used the most tiles.

Paper Airplane Flying Game is a dexterity game where players fold paper airplanes and then fly them toward a board representing a landing strip, trying to land them in the highest point value areas. The highest point value areas are both smaller and further away, making it harder to score higher point values.

Description from the package: "First, fold your paper airplanes following the instructions. Next, stand 2-3 paces from the front of the game board. Throw a plane and try to land it on the runway, aiming for the highest points. Let each player take a few practice turns. Then, throw one plane per turn. Whoever has the most points at the end of the game wins!"

Players may decide on their own how many turns to play and how to score plane points (i.e. exactly where the plane must land and how it must be placed to score points for section it lands in.)

name.value: Curious George Adventures Pop-Up Candy Game

item.description:
In Curious George Adventures Pop-Up Candy Game, players compete to be the first to reach the Man in the Yellow Hat while collecting as much candy as possible along the way.

The game comes with packages of Rascals candy, which are placed in the candy circle on the board. Players choose a game piece and place it on the start square. They take turns rolling a die marked with various fruits, then move their piece to the next matching fruit on the track. Along the way, players may land on spaces that cause them to move forward or backward or lose or gain candy. Some spaces have pop-open doors which have hidden instructions inside. The first player to reach the end of the track wins and gets to eat all his earned candy. Other players must return their candy to the candy circle and go hungry.

From the box: "Practice number recognition and basic addition with this fun apple-picking game."

In Apple Addition, each player uses a two-sided card shaped like an apple tree. There are two way to play.

Level 1 - Pick & Match Apples: Each player takes an apple tree card showing several numbers. Players then take turns randomly choosing an apple marker from the box. Each marker shows a number of apple seeds. The player must correctly count the seeds and then, if it matches a number on their card, place it over the number. The marker is then flipped. If the player counted correctly and the number matches, the marker stays on the card. If the number does not match one on the player's card or the player counts wrong, the marker goes back in the box. If the player draws an apple with a worm, he or she must put an apple from his tree back on the box. An apple core causes loss of a turn. First player to cover all the numbers on his or her tree wins.

Level 2 - Apple Addition: Each tree displays three addition problems. The game is played by the same rules. The first player to find the answers to all three math problems wins.

The object of the game is to survive your journey and enter the palace. Along the way you are challenged by masters of ancient oriental weapons, pick and pass cards and spaces you land on. Also you are confronted by with the pit, which is the house of Dim Mak, and by the March, which is guarded by the fearful dragon.
You are competing with palace ninja all along the way. Each player can attack or challenge opposing players during his journey. Combative point tokens are exchanged. Spinning shuriken wheel is used to advance each players ninja.

Similar to Celebrities, Say What? is played in three rounds.

Say What? contains dice, a minute glass and 160 cards with four things on each card.

Before each round each team rolls a die to decide whether they have to describe celebrities, characters, works of fiction or things. They then have one minute to describe as many as possible.

In the first round, you can say anything except any part of what's on the card!

In the second round, you can only say one word!

In the third round, you can only use charades!

Are you brave enough to enter the Brawlzone and start Brawlin' with your 'Rookie Deck'? The fast-paced card game, packed full of mini zombies all with attitude. Power-up your zombies and become unstoppable, use your Rare & Super Rare zombie cards to be UNBEATABLE! Pick-up and Play - Play Anywhere - There's always a chance to win. 50/50 Play:The Rookie Deck has been designed so it can be split equally between two players, so each player can use 20 Zombie Cards and 5 Add-on Cards. Using 50/50 play means that if your friend, Brother or Sister doesn't have a deck or has forgotten theirs, they can still play this great Zombie card game! Simple and easy game-play makes Zombie Brawlerz great fun straight out of the box.

Zombie Brawlerz is a top trumps mechanic game with strategy cards that alter the dynamics of each round, with incredible cartoon style zombie artwork.

A poem on the box describes the game: "A Thoughtful Girl must dress with care. / What goes with what? What shall you wear? / The spinner says to pick some shoes. / But only YOU know which you'll choose. / And with your clothing you'll select / the hobby that you most respect. / Pursue your vision with a passion-- / There's more to life than only fashion! / The first one dressed and on her way / has won the game. / Do you want to play?"

Each player chooses a paper doll and take turns spinning the spinner. The spinner will tell them which piece of clothing or accessory to add to their doll. One space on the spinner requires the spinner to lose a piece. The first player to completely dress and equip his or her doll wins.

The game is notable for its diverse paper doll characters, multi-ethnic outfits and selection of hobbies that is less stereotypically girly, such as astronomy, guitar and science.

I Remember: a Matching Game is part of the Crayola Games line. It is a new twist on the classic game Memory. Like Memory, a collection of tiles is placed face-down. In I Remember, a spinner is added and tiles are assigned to one of four categories (food, animals, toys or transportation). The game can be played at three levels. Level one is played with only one category of tiles, reducing the number to make matching easier. Game play is identical to Memory--players turn over two tiles trying to find a match. If the tiles match, the player keeps them. If not, they are replaced in the same positions and the next player plays. When all tiles have been claimed, the player with the most tiles wins.

In level two, players spin the spinner to determine which of four categories they must match. The current player then turns over a single tile. If it matches the category spun, the player keeps the tile. If not, it is replaced in its original position. The next player then attempts to match the same category. Once a match is made, the next player spins to determine the new category and play continues. When all tiles have been claimed, the player with the most tiles wins.

Level three is played in a similar way to level two, except after spinning players must find two tiles with matching pictures in the category spun.

name.value: Spin Doctor: The Card game of Dirty Politics

item.description: Spin Doctor: The Card game of Dirty Politics is a card game for 2 to 6 (or more) players wherein the players take on the role of candidates running for President of the United States. During the course of the game, players will accumulate votes by collecting state cards while at the same time thwarting their opponent’s ability to do the same by putting them in scandal, winning debates, being underhanded and generally behaving like a mud slinging politician!

Family Happenings is a roll-and-move game designed to be used as a tool for stimulating discussions during therapy sessions with children. The rules note that it "should only be used by a trained professional."

In the game, players roll a die to move pawns on a track. As they move, they land on various types of spaces. On Feeling Card spaces, the player must draw a card with a feeling printed on it and describe a time when he or she experienced that feeling. On a Do A Stunt space, the player draws a card and performs the action printed on it. On a Mail space, a card with the start of the first sentence of a letter written to a friend or family member is drawn. The player must complete the sentence. On a Family Happenings space, the player draws a card with a question that refers to a family problem that the child may have experienced (cards are marked with categories so the therapist can customize the deck to his clients). The player must answer the question. Roll 'n Go squares occur at junctions in the path and allow the player to roll again and move in a direction determined by their roll. Sent To Your Room squared require the player to go to their "room," a space marked with their pawn's color. They must then answer the question in their room before rolling to leave the room on their next turn. On a Spin space, the player spins a spinner and may gain or lose a turn or gain or lose chips depending on the roll. At the end of each player's turn, he or she receives one chip as allowance.

Players attempt to reach the end of the track, which if the peak of the roof on the house-shaped track. The game may end in one of two ways. The first player to reach the peak of the house can be declared the winner, or a time limit can be imposed, with the player holding the most chips when time runs out winning. In this version, reaching the finish space brings a bonus of five chips, after which the player may continue to move on the track.

Description from the publisher:

In Adventure Land, King Agamis rules from his castle. Rich cities, vast forests and rugged mountain ranges dominate the country. The large river is known to be lined with gold and the forests filled with medicinal herbs, but dangers lurk beneath the fog! Only the bravest adventurers dare to face the challenges. When you move your adventurer tactically and bravely fight the fog creatures, you'll win the favor of the king. Illustrated by Franz Vohwinkel and designed by acclaimed duo Wolfgang Kramer and Michael Kiesling who between them have won the highly coveted Spiel des Jahres award 5 times.

There are three different adventure scenarios to choose from, depending on the age/skill of the players: 
-Adventure 1 (The Fellowship ) the simplest of the three adventures
-Adventure 2 (The Magnificent) a little more challenging
-Adventure 3 (Escape to the Cities) the most challenging because there are many things to pay attention to simultaneously

item.description: A simplified variation on the classic Rummikub game of playing numbered tiles in sets and runs. Features 10 numbered tiles per suit rather than 13. It can be played at three levels of complexity: beginner, allowing runs or sets of two or more tiles with no jokers; intermediate, adding the jokers; and advanced, requiring sets and runs of at least three tiles as in regular Rummikub.

item.description:
In What Do You See? Colors, players choose face-down cards, trying to be the first to complete a set and win the game. There are three different ways to play.


 Search and Match Colors - Each player takes a card marked with a colored star designating which color he or she will collect. Picture cards are placed face-up in the center of the table. Each player in turn takes a card to match their color. If the color matches, the player keeps the card. If not, he or she must put it back. Play continues until all players have six matched color cards. This game is for very young players, and is meant to teach color recognition.



 Seven That Match - This game is played similarly to Search and Match Colors. In this version, each player has two color cards to match. Cards are placed face down. Players pick one card at a time and try to match it to one of their cards. If it matches, the player keeps the card. If not, it goes back to the center face down. The first player to collect six cards matching the color of one of his or her star cards wins.



 What Color Do You See? - In this version, each player has a game board with spaces for eight different colors. All cards are placed face-down on the table. Players take turns choosing a face-down card. If the player doesn't yet have the color, he or she covers the corresponding space on his or her card. If he or she does have the color, the card goes back face down. In this version, there are also wild cards, which can be placed on any color. The first player to cover all colors on the card wins the game.

It’s a fur-flying frenzy for the late Olga’s cash!

For weeks, the nation has been captivated by the competition to win the fortune of the late Olga. The rules are simple, the one who takes care of all the cats wins. But contestants are running out of patience as their opponents resort to tossing cats and outright sabotage. There’s only a handful of contenders left, will you be the last caretaker standing?

Feline Fortunes is a card game for 2-4 players that plays in 20-30 minutes. In the game you’ll need to manage the cats in your Lap, defending yourself and attacking others. If you run out of Patience, you’re out of the game, and the last player to keep their wits is the winner.
 COLLECT CATS
Gather Olga’s cats into your Lap and show the world you’re the best caretaker. Gather 3 or more and you’ll get back some of your precious Patience as they purr.

TOSS CATS
If a cat falls off your Lap, you can toss it at an opponent to wreak havoc with their play space. You don’t win the cash by playing nice, after all.

UNIQUE CATS
Cats can push each other, fight with one another, launch other cats and even copy each other’s abilities. With more than 60 cat cards, who knows what will pounce into your Lap next.

STRATEGIC CATS
All information is open in Feline Fortunes, so you always know what you’re opponents are capable of. But a single move can dramatically affect the entire game, so don’t get too comfortable, buddy.

The lonely dweller of the lighthouse was sailing back to his lookout packed with food when a huge, all-consuming storm started. The raging waves consumed the ship and its load, too. Luckily, he escaped and pulled through the storm on a lonely rock. Four sailboats set out after him competing with each other to hurry to his aid.

There is six wind strength discs (which mark the steps), that lay face down at one end of the board. First player turns over any of the wind strength discs and takes as many steps as shown on the disc. After everyone has looked at the disc, he turns it back over immediately. There is two rules:

 The total number of steps on the disc have to be taken.
 You can step forwards or backwards, but only in one direction at a time, you can’t change direction while in motion!




If somebody steps on the field where the guard of the lighthouse got shipwrecked, he has to place guard in the boat and continue the trip with him (since the aim is to reach the goal together with him)! If player placed him in the boat, he has to mix the wind strength discs at once, before the next player’s turn. This makes the game harder, since the discs memorized so far change their places. The goal is still to arrive on the field where the guard or the ship transporting the guard is standing. According to some rules, the guard can change the boat.

The player who first docks at the isle of the lighthouse with the guard sitting in his or her boat, wins.
